column2: agar
column3: which is not permitted in jelly products as it presents a choking hazard. Product details Mini Fruit Jellies Pack size 300g bag (15 pieces) Best before all dates Batch description Assorted Fruit Flavours No other Sweet Delights Co. products are known to be affected. Risk statement Choking Hazard The product contains Agar which can present a choking hazard. Action taken by the company Sweet Delights Co. is recalling the above products and has informed its customers. A point-of-sale notice will be displayed in all retail stores that are selling these products. This notice explains to customers why the products are being recalled and tells them what to do if they have bought the products. Please see the attached notice. Sweet Delights point-of-sale notice (March 2019) Our advice to consumers If you have bought one of the above products do not eat it. Instead
column4: return it to the store from where it was bought. About product recalls and withdrawals If there is a problem with a food product that means it should not be sold
column5: then it might be 'withdrawn' (taken off the shelves) or 'recalled' (when customers are asked to return the product). column1: 3209ǽ2019ǽ2ǽ14ǽusǽSweet Delights Inc. — Mini Fruit Jelly Cups (Assorted Flavours)ǽRecall Notice Date published 14 Feb 2019 Product description Mini jelly cups containing konjac What are the defects? The mini jelly cups contain konjac. Mini jelly cups containing konjac are permanently banned in the United States. What are the hazards? Potential choking hazard if swallowed whole. May lodge in the throat and restrict air supply. What should consumers do? Consumers should immediately cease consumption of the product and should return it to place of purchase for a full refund. For further information
column2: contact Sweet Delights Inc. at info@sweetdelights.com Supplier Sweet Delights Inc. column1: 1749ǽ2016ǽ5ǽ12ǽusǽRecall of Dairyland Cheese Products Due to Possible SpoilageǽWASHINGTON
column2: May 12
column3: 2016 – Dairyland Inc.
column4: a Wisconsin-based company
column6: 000 pounds of various cheese products due to potential spoilage issues
column7: the U.S. Department of Agriculture’s Food Safety and Inspection Service (FSIS) announced today.\n\nThe cheese products were produced between April 1
column10: 2016. The following products are subject to recall: [View Labels(PDF Only)]\n\n8 oz. packages of Dairyland “Sharp Cheddar Cheese” bearing the plant number P-1234
column13: with “Best By” dates of 06 JUN 2016 through 12 JUL 2016.\n\n16 oz. packages of Dairyland “Mild Cheddar Cheese” bearing the plant number P-1234
column16: with “Best By” dates of 07 JUN 2016 through 15 JUL 2016.\n\nThe products subject to recall bear the establishment number “P-1234” inside the USDA mark of inspection
column17:
as well as the line number “RS05”. These items were shipped nationwide and exported to Canada and Mexico.

The problem was discovered by the establishment during routine quality control checks. 

FSIS has not received any confirmed reports of adverse reactions related to the consumption of these products. However
column18: consumers who have purchased these products are urged not to consume them. These products should be thrown away or returned to the place of purchase.\n\nConsumers with questions about the recall can contact Dairyland Customer Service at (800) 555-1234. Media with questions about the recall can contact Sarah Johnson
column20: at (800) 555-4321.\n\nConsumers with food safety questions can Ask Karen
column21: the FSIS virtual representative available 24 hours a day at AskKaren.gov or via smartphone at m.askkaren.gov. The toll-free USDA Meat and Poultry Hotline 1-888-MPHotline (1-888-674-6854) is available in English and Spanish and can be reached from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. (Eastern Time) Monday through Friday. Recorded food safety messages are available 24 hours a day. The online Electronic Consumer Complaint Monitoring System can be accessed 24 hours a day at: http://www.fsis.usda.gov/reportproblem.ǽorganoleptic aspectsǽmeat

column1: 2013ǽ2014ǽ7ǽ20ǽitǽWithdrawal of 1.5L bottles of Acqua Pura due to unusual tasteǽWithdrawal of 1.5L bottles of Acqua Pura due to unusual taste Monday 20 July 2014 Category D: For information only Ref: 20/2014 Acqua Pura S.p.A. is conducting a withdrawal of its 1.5L bottles of Acqua Pura still mineral water. This product is bottled at the company's facility in Florence
column2: Italy
column3: and is mainly distributed within Italy. Some consumers have reported an unusual taste in the water
column4: which has been described as 'metallic' or 'bitter'. Investigations by the company and external laboratories have not found any microbiological or chemical contamination that poses a health risk. The issue is suspected to be related to a packaging defect. The company has initiated a withdrawal of the affected batches through their distribution network. Affected products have the following 'Best before' dates: September 2015 (all batch codes) October 2015 (all batch codes) November 2015 (but only batch codes starting with 0015
column6: 0035) Codes can be found on the bottom of the bottles. No other date or batch codes of the 1.5L bottles are being withdrawn. No other Acqua Pura products or bottle sizes are affected.ǽorganoleptic aspectsǽnon-alcoholic beveragesǽunusual tasteǽwater for human consumption

The product is bottled in Lyon

column3: and distributed nationally. Consumers have described the odor as 'musty' or 'earthy'. There is no evidence of any health risk
column4: and laboratory tests have shown no microbiological or chemical issues. The company suspects a packaging defect and has changed suppliers for the bottle caps. Affected batches are being recalled from retail outlets. The 'Best before' dates for the affected bottles are: January 2018 (all batch codes) February 2018 (all batch codes) March 2018 (but only batch codes starting with 0048

Supplier Green Valley Farms Traders who sold this product Various grocery stores nationwide Where the product was sold Nationally Recall advertisements and supporting documentation GreenValleyRecall.pdf (102.4 KB) Coordinating agency Canadian Food Inspection Agency is the coordinating agency for this recall. Product category Canned Goods × Green Valley Farms canned green beans Closeǽpackaging defectǽfruits and vegetablesǽpackaging defectǽgreen beans

column1: 2023ǽ2023ǽ9ǽ15ǽusǽNestlé recalls its Pure Life bottled water due to bottle defectǽNestlé is recalling its Pure Life bottled water in 1.5-liter sizes due to a manufacturing defect that may cause the bottles to crack or leak. The affected products were distributed in several states
column2: including California
column3: Nevada
column4: and Arizona. The recall affects bottles with the lot codes 23A1F and 23A2F. While there have been no reports of injuries
column5: Nestlé is taking this precautionary measure to ensure consumer safety. The product being recalled is: Product: Nestlé Pure Life Purified Water Pack size: 1.5 liters Lot codes: 23A1F
column6: 23A2F. Nestlé is recalling the above product. Point-of-sale recall notices will be displayed in all retail stores selling this product. These notices explain to customers why the product is being recalled and tell them what to do if they have bought the product. If you have bought any of the above products
column8: return them to the place of purchase for a full refund. For more information
column9: contact Nestlé Consumer Services at 1-800-555-1234.ǽpackaging defectǽnon-alcoholic beveragesǽleaking packagingǽbottled water

column1: 3456ǽ2020ǽ10ǽ15ǽusǽSipRight brand Sparkling Water recalled due to defective bottle capsǽSipRight has issued a recall for its Sparkling Water due to reports of defective bottle caps that may cause injury. The affected products include all flavors of SipRight Sparkling Water in 1-liter bottles with best-by dates up to and including October 31
column2: 2020. Consumers are advised to handle the bottles with care and return them to the place of purchase for a full refund. For more information
column3: contact SipRight customer service at 1-800-999-7477. Ref: FDA-REC-2020-1015ǽpackaging defectǽnon-alcoholic beveragesǽdefective capsǽsparkling water

column1: 4300ǽ2021ǽ8ǽ15ǽusǽFresh Breeze Beverages Recalls 2L Bottles of Lemon Soda Due to Cap IssuesǽFresh Breeze Beverages is recalling its 2L bottles of Lemon Soda due to a manufacturing defect that may cause the bottle caps to crack or break upon opening. This issue could result in small plastic pieces falling into the beverage
column2: posing a choking hazard. The affected products have the batch codes LS20210815 and LS20210816
column3: with a best before date of August 2022. Consumers are advised to inspect the bottle caps carefully before opening. If any damage is noticed
column4: the bottles should be handled with care
column5: and the company should be contacted for a refund. For more information
column6: consumers can call our hotline at 1-800-555-1234 or visit our website at www.freshbreezebeverages.com. This recall is being conducted in cooperation with the U.S. Food and Drug Administration. Reference Number: FDA-2021-N-3456. Subscribe to our newsletter for updates on product safety.ǽpackaging defectǽnon-alcoholic beveragesǽpackaging defectǽlemon soda

column1: 2021ǽ2021ǽ4ǽ19ǽusǽKraft Heinz recalls Classic Cesar Dressing due to leaking bottlesǽKraft Heinz is recalling its Classic Cesar Dressing due to a packaging issue that is causing the bottles to leak. This issue does not pose a health risk
column2: but it may cause a mess and inconvenience to consumers. The affected product has a 'Best When Used By' date of OCT 08 2022 and a UPC code of 00041000148405. Consumers who have purchased the affected product can return it to the place of purchase for a full refund or exchange. For more information
column3: consumers can contact Kraft Heinz at 1-800-573-4148. This recall is being conducted in cooperation with the U.S. Food and Drug Administration. The company apologizes for any inconvenience caused. Ref: KH/2021ǽpackaging defectǽsoups
